metadata.titleEn: Cenozoic stratigraphic data of Nepal in the southern Tibetan Plateau
metadata.description: Nepal is in the southern Tibetan Plateau. The Cenozoic strata developed in Nepal contain fruitful information on the tectonic evolution, paleoenvironment and paleoclimate changes. It's very significant in revealing the history of the uplift and deformation of the Tibetan Plateau and its relevant effects on the regional and even global environment and climate. This data set contains several well-developed Cenozoic sections from northern and central Nepal, which have been identified by the systematic geological survey. Depending on the tools (e.g. GPS, geological compass) in the fieldwork, we have finished the geological measurements and descriptions of these sections as well as the relevant geological maps. The Butwa section is located in the Tansen area of central Nepal, about 320-m deposit with coals and consists of Taltung Formation, Amile Formation, Bhainskati Formation and Dumri Formation from bottom to top. The Kalyan section is in the northwestern Birendranagar of northern Nepal, about 1160-m deposit with biogenic limestones and abundant microfossils. The lower part is Bhainskati Formation and the upper part is Dumri Formation. This data set provides a solid geological foundation for the following research in the southern Tibetan Plateau on stratigraphic chronology, tectonic evolution, paleoenvironment and paleoclimate, and so forth.
metadata.instructions: The data file is named “Cenozoic stratigraphic data in the Southern Tibetan Plateau” based on its content. It was stored as a .docx file and can be opened and read by the Word program directly.

literatureList.titleEn: Constraints on the timing of the India-Asia collision and unroofing history of the Himalayan orogen using detrital zircon U-Pb-Hf and whole-rock Sr-Nd isotopes in Cretaceous-Miocene Lesser Himalayan sedimentary rocks
literatureList.referenceEn: Feng, W., Meng, Q.Q., Song, C.H., Fang, X.M., Zhuang, G.S., He, P.J., Yang, S.F., Zhang, J., Chen, Y.F., & Zhang, Y.H. (2022). Constraints on the timing of the India-Asia collision and unroofing history of the Himalayan orogen using detrital zircon U-Pb-Hf and whole-rock Sr-Nd isotopes in Cretaceous-Miocene Lesser Himalayan sedimentary rocks. Basin Research, doi: 10.1111/bre.12742.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific techniques used for measuring and describing the lithology, structure, and geomorphology in a geological profile?

Quantification.Question: How many meters thick is the Butwal geological section studied in the southern Tibetan Plateau region?

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using GPS and geological compasses in geological data collection?
Definition.Answer: GPS and geological compasses are critical tools for conducting accurate field measurements in geological data collection. They help researchers determine precise locations and orientations of geological features, which is essential for mapping and describing structural, geomorphological, and lithological characteristics of stratigraphic sections.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in accurately describing the geological features of the Cenozoic strata in southern Tibet and Nepal?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Accurate description of the geological features of the Cenozoic strata in southern Tibet and Nepal can be challenging due to the complex tectonic, environmental, and climatic conditions of the region. The use of tools such as GPS and geological compasses is necessary to conduct thorough surveys and measurements of the structures, geomorphology, and lithology of well-developed research sections. These challenges are compounded by the need for detailed mapping and documentation of these features, which are essential for understanding the uplift, deformation, and climatic effects of the Tibetan Plateau.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using GPS and geological compasses for data collection on the accuracy and detail of geological surveys in the southern Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using GPS and geological compasses for data collection allows for precise measurement and description of structural, geomorphological, and lithological features, enhancing the accuracy and detail of geological surveys. This method helps in identifying well-developed research profiles and contributes to the creation of detailed maps and diagrams, which are crucial for understanding the tectonic, environmental, and climatic evolution in the southern Tibetan Plateau.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed to systematically conduct field geological surveys for Cenozoic stratigraphy in the southern Tibetan Plateau, and how are tools like GPS and geological compasses utilized in these surveys?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The methodologies involve systematic field geological surveys to identify well-developed study sections in the southern Tibetan Plateau, specifically in Nepal. Tools such as GPS and geological compasses are used for conducting structural, geomorphological, and lithological investigations and measurements. These tools aid in the accurate description and mapping of related profiles.
